If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im S. (was in the photo), 51, and her husband, Mr. Chheng Vorng, 53, have been married since 1979 and have five children-three sons and two daughter. Unfortunately, one of her sons died. The family is living in a small village on National Road number 2 about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Im and her husband are farmers. She hopes to generate income by raising and cows. So, she is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase cows to raise.  

When the cows give birth, she will be able to earn more income from selling the calves or when the cows grow to full size, she will be able to sell the cows for beef. 

Photo: Mrs. Im S. is at home, was not at the farm

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise

loans.name: Etaf

texts.en:
Etaf A. M. is a mother of two sons and one daughter. Etaf's husband passed away, leaving her responsible for taking care of the family. Etaf's children are old enough now to work with her. She wanted to start a family business and have her sons working there.

A year and a half ago, Etaf started a small poultry farm on the rooftop of her house. She raises chicken and prepares them for cooking to be sold to neighbors. Etaf's returns are good but she wants to enlarge the project and cover a larger area, so she came to FATEN and took a loan to purchase coops and feeding trays.

Etaf hopes that one day she can rent a bigger place and have a proper farm, providing better opportunities for her children. Etaf's son appears in the picture here on the farm as Etaf is very religious and uncomfortable having her picture online.

Important information about this loan:
 
FFATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the culturA. context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principA. loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit our FAQs.

loans.use: To improve the farm by purchasing coops and feeding trays

loans.name: Sok-Heang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok-heang K. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Porn Khut, have been married since 1981 and have nine children--four sons and five daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sok-heang and her husband are rice and vegetable farmers. When she is not at the farm, she also supplements her income with a new business selling fish to earn additional income to support her family. 

Sok-heang hopes to buy more fish for resale, so she is requesting her second loan of US$ 300.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Sabrina

texts.en:
Sabrina Q. is from the village of Clarin, Plaridel, Mis. Occ. She is 38 years old. Sabrina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sabrina owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Sabrina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Sabrina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sabrina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Sabrina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Sabrina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sot

texts.en:
Mrs. Sot S. (pictured with her loom and her daughter), 40, and her husband, Mr. Sopha Bou, 39, have been married since 1993 and have one daughter. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sot is a weaver. Mr. Sopha Bou sells silk and cotton products. He buys them from other weavers the village and some from his wife and sells to middleman who comes to buy them at his home.  

Sot is requesting her first loan of US$ 700 to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and buy silk and cotton products for resale.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and buy silk and cotton products for resale

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima B. is the leader of this group. She is 44, married. Together with her husband, who has a profession as a Russian language teacher, she is bringing up two children; both of them are school pupils. Fatima works as a head of studies in the local school. Concurrently the family earns additional income from cattle breeding, which helps to satisfy their daily requirements. The loan purpose is to purchase two calves in order to increase their herd.

Fatima’s partners:

Jyrgal A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 38, married. Her family has a son. The main family income derives from cattle breeding; besides that, Jyrgal works as a school teacher. The loan purpose is to purchase 2 calves to expand their herd. 

Gulmira S., 38, is married. Together with her husband, she is raising three children. The family is engaged in trading, they own a foodstuffs shop. The loan purpose is to purchase drinks, cigarettes, and macaroni to expand their assortment of goods. 

Gulkayir D., 41, is married. Her husband earns money by working as a taxi-driver; the couple is raising two children. Besides that, the family gets income out of clothes selling. The loan purpose is to purchase more clothes for further resale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single man living with his parents in Lebanon. He has more than nine years of experience repairing motorcycles. He has a small space at the entrance of his home that he has prepared to receive motorcycles.  This talented young man works very hard to help his father cover the heavy expenses of the family, and in addition he is trying to improve his business. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new tools and motorcycle spare parts. In the future, he is planning to open a formA. motorcycle repair shop.

loans.use: to purchase new tools and motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Rehma

texts.en: Rehma is 30 years old. She is married and has three children between the ages of two and ten. Her children go to school. Her husband works as a taxi driver and Rehma sells clothes. She has had this business for ten years. With this loan she will buy more clothes to sell. With the profit she will put aside savings. Her business is successful because she serves many customers. In future, Rehma would like to make 50% return on her investment.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Juevil

texts.en:
Juevil M. is from the village of Bunawan, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old. Juevil is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Juevil owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motor services to local community members. Juevil has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juevil joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juevil is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Juevil from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide sufficient services

loans.name: Chenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chenda B. is 30 years old and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Thai is 31 years old. They have been married since 2004 and have three children--two sons and one daughter. One of them is in school and the two others are still young and stay at home. The family lives along National Road Number One, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Chenda and her husband are farmers. They grow cauliflower on their farmland in the village and sell their products to a middleman who comes to buy them at their home. The couple does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their cauliflower farm. 

Hence Chenda is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to provide her capital. 

Note: In the photo the couple are at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mr. Sarin P. and his wife Mrs. Sokha Born, have been married for more than twenty-two years and have five children--two sons and three daughters. The family lives along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sarin and his wife are vegetable farmers. He asked for a Kiva loan once already, and he now is asking for his second loan of $1,200 to continue his farming business by buying seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

The couple are both in the picture.

loans.use: buying seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a young man from Jabalia refugee camp. He is married and has no children. Muhammad owns a motorcycle workshop. He fixes motorcycles, replaces parts and provides all related services. The number of motorcycles is increasing in the region, so Muhammad came to FATEN to take out a loan to purchase new tools and necessary parts. Muhammad's workshop is one of the very rare ones in Jabalia. He has a good number of clients and would like to increase them by providing better services. Muhammad appears in the picture here in his workshop.

<u>Important information about this loan:</u>
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the culturA. context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principA. loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit our FAQs.

loans.use: To purchase tools and parts

loans.name: John Macharia

texts.en: John started selling electrical goods in the town of Olkalou early this year and quickly discovered that this business can be profitable.  He is 28 years old, married to Damaris Wachera Kinyanjui and has two children. He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and has applied for his first loan.  He plans to use the money to buy more electrical goods to sell. In the future, John hopes to open a bigger shop in his town.

loans.use: To buy more electrical goods to sell.

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.en:
Alejandro T. lives in the village of Southwestern Pob., Calamba Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old, married and has five school-aged children. He makes a living by running a retail store where he sells products people use daily such as shampoo, soap, candies, biscuits and toothpaste. He has made a living doing this for more than 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Alejandro joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He has successfully repaid two previous loans from GDMPC and is applying for a new one, for 15,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by his business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to his customers

loans.name: Bunnarith

texts.en: Mr. Bunnarith is 40 years old and married to Mrs. Sophea Chhea, who is 36 years old. They have been married since 1993 and have two children, one son and one daughter. The family lives along National Road No. 1 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. For the last 14 years, Bunnarith has earned a living by driving a remoque or motorcycle with a trailer at the back. His wife makes a living by selling porridge and cakes at home. Bunnarith hopes to upgrade his vehicle to a tuk tuk or rickshaw, and is applying for a loan to buy one.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is a dairy farmer who lives in the town of Kitale in western Kenya. He has been farming for three years and has two employees. His main product is milk, which he sells in the local market. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of maize. He has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and provide for the basic needs of his family. He says that his major problem has been various diseases which are costly to treat. In the future, he would like to acquire five high-quality dairy cows able to produce more than 60 litres of milk daily.

Solomon is 35 years old. He is married and has been blessed with four children who range in age from 2 to 11. Three of his children are currently in school.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jane Wanjiku

texts.en: Jane has made a living selling clothes in the town of Olkalou since 2001. She is 38 years old, married to Paul Huri Maina and has four children. She was introduced to KADET by a friend and has applied for her first loan. She plans to use the loan to buy more clothing to sell to her customers. She is eager to buy these clothes before the December holiday season, when her sales normally peak.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sop Serigne Fallou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOP SERIGNE FALLOU est créé le 28 mars 2007. Il est composé de 03 femmes qui habitent la même concession et nouent de très bonnes relations amicales. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de THIECKENE-LOUGA

Madame AWA B. à droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée 30 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge. 

Elle fait du petit commerce et de l'embouche ovine depuis son intégration dans le Banc Villageois.

Son crédit lui permettra d'amplifier son activité en augmentant son niveau d'approvisionnement et d'acheter un mouton.

Son objectif est de subvenir aux besoins de la famille
texts.en:
The Sop Serigne Fallou Solidarity group was created on 28 March 2007. It is composed of 3 women who live in the same area and have established excellent social relations with each other. The group is a member of the Village Loan fund of Thieckene-Louga.

Ms. Awa B., on the right in the photo, is responsible for the group. She is 30 years old, married, and is the mother of 6 children who are in her care.

She has run a small business raising sheep since joining the Village Loan fund.

This loan will allow her to expand her business by increasing her supplies and letting her buy a sheep.

Her goal is to provide for her family.

loans.use: To expand and promote her income-generating activity.

loans.name: Islam

texts.en:
Islam is a very young man from Jabalia refugee camp. He is married and has one son. Islam started his project two years ago – he established a sheep farm in the refugee camp. Islam wants to secure his family life by enlarging the project. He came to Kiva's partner, FATEN, and took out a loan to purchase sheep to raise for sale, especially now that Al-Adha feast is around the corner and he expects demand to increase.

Islam appears in his farm in the photo.

Important information about this loan:

FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's FAQs.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Altanzagas

texts.en:
Altanzagas J. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She lives together with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest son currently attends a vocational training program. Altanzagas and her family operate a sausage production business in the local community. They started their business with a small factory in Darhan province in 2005, and in 2009 they moved to their current site. After years of successful operations they have built a stable business and gained experience. 

In the future, Altanzagas hopes to expand her business by producing a wider variety of sausage products such as double-smoked sausages and liver pudding. Her business is very important to Altanzagas and her family and she dreams of one day being able to have her own house and fence. Altanzagas is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary equipment for her factory.

loans.use: to purchase necessary equipment

loans.name: Bathishig

texts.en:
Bathishig C. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Bathishig and his wife operate a clothing retail business and have two shops in their town. His wife sells a variety of clothes in a rented stall the local trade center while Bathishig sells from a rented container in the local market. Bathishig first started his clothing business in 2008 by traveling to the Chinese border city of Erlian to purchase clothing items and transporting them back to his shop. Bathishig quickly became successful and has achieved a stable business. 

Bathishig and his wife are very hardworking people and have used their business income to greatly improve their quality of life. In the future, Bathishig plans to have his own workplace. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more items for his clothing business to increase his working capital.

loans.use: to purchase more items of clothing

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira A. lives in Sokuluk village and is the single mother of two girls. Elmira works as a hairdresser, but her salary is low and does not cover all of her family expenses. Therefore, in 2005, Elmira started a business to create an additional means of income. She converted one of the rooms in her flat into a small shop and started selling groceries. 

Elmira is requesting a loan of 60,000 KGS to use to expand the assortment of goods she offers for sale. With the revenue from the loan she plans to provide a good education for her children.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners:

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable populations. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to expand the assortment of goods for sale

loans.name: Hishigjargal

texts.en:
Hishigjargal S. is a 30-year-old single woman who lives with her parents and three siblings in Huvsgul province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her father is a carpenter and her mother is retired. Hishigjargal operates a beauty salon in her town. She started her salon in 2009 after graduating from vocational school with beautician training. Hishigjargal’s business is important to her, as her earnings have enabled her to support her family.

Hishigjargal is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary tools and equipment for her beauty salon and to decorate her workplace. In the future, she hopes to improve her workplace and provide unique and good services to customers to increase her customer base.

loans.use: to purchase necessary tools and equipment

loans.name: Joyce Wamaitha

texts.en:
Joyce is 36 years old and married to K. Mwai. They have three children. For the last nine years, Joyce has operated a food stall in Olkalou town. She also is a farmer. 

Joyce was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her second loan.  She repaid her previous loan easily and in good time.  She plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer for her farm and bulk dry goods for her food stall. 

In the future, Joyce hopes to expand her food stall to be able to serve more customers at a time.

loans.use: to buy dry goods for the food stall and fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Seeten

texts.en:
Seeten S. is a 51-year-old widow who lives with her son in Bayanhoshuu Mongolia. Her 18 year-old son attends high school. She and her son live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and Seeten operates a hair salon in her town. She has been working as a hairdresser since 2007 and has built a stable operation. 

For the future, Seeten hopes to expand her business and provide a good education for her son. She needs funds to expand her workplace and she would like to start selling cosmetics at her hair salon. Seeten is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital and earnings.

loans.use: to increase working capital and start selling cosmetics

loans.name: Tserenbyamba

texts.en: Tserenbyamba T. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in her parents' yard. Her daughter attends a local primary school while her husband works as a driver. Tserenbyamba operates a car spare parts trading business in her local town. She sells a variety of machinery parts through her two shops. She started her business in 2006 selling spare parts at the local market and has built a stable and successful operation. In 2008, she used her earnings to build a new workplace where she operates her business. Over the years, she has managed to expand her business by renting one more stall in the local market and now sells products through her two different shops. Her earnings have enabled her to buy a car for her family. Today her working capital has reached up to 5,000,000 MNT. She hopes to one day have her own house and fence where her family can live. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to buy machinery parts to sell.

loans.use: To buy machinery parts

loans.name: Nina's Group

texts.en:
Nina A. is the leader of the group. She is 58 and married. Her husband works in the business of goods transportation. Besides running the family business, cattle breeding, Nina is also a chemistry and biology teacher. The family’s total income makes it possible to satisfy their daily requirements. The family wants to purchase a calf in order to increase cattle stock, and is requesting a loan for this purpose.

Nina’s partners:
Janyl I., 52, married. Janyl is a Kyrgyz language and literature teacher. Because of the low salary, the family has to breed cattle in order to increase their total income. Janyl wants to obtain 3 sheep, and is requesting a loan for this purpose.

Chabagan K., 50, married. She is a Russian language and literature teacher. Her family is also engaged in cattle breeding. Her loan request is to purchase 2 calves for fattening.

Kulzada S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 44, married. She makes her living as a mathematics teacher. Her family earns additional income by breeding cattle. The loan purpose is to buy 2 calves to increase their stock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Zina's Group

texts.en:
Zina A. is the leader of the group. She is 57 and married. She has 3 children; the youngest of them lives at home and helps run their business- farming and cattle breeding. Over the years, the family has managed to increase cattle stock. In order to develop this business, Zina wants to purchase more cattle, and is requesting a loan for this purpose. In the future she is planning to arrange her son’s marriage.

Zina’s partners:

Anarkul K., 63, a widow. Her family has 8 children; most of them are adults and live separately, except the 2 youngest. With the help of her daughter, Anarkul is engaged in cattle breeding and farming. The loan purpose is to increase cattle stock.

Maksuda T., 52, a widow. She has 8 children; the youngest son helps his mother to earn money by farming. The loan purpose is to obtain necessary equipment for ground weeding. 

Kymbat J., 57, married. She is the treasurer of the group. Her family has 6 children; all but the youngest one are married. The family makes their livelihood by cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase more cattle for increasing the total number of animals. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Ernest Nganga

texts.en:
Ernest is married and they have one child. He was introduced to KADET LTD by a Credit Officer, and he is servicing a second loan as he has paid the first loan successfully. Ernest has been in the clothing business for ten years. Ernest shall use the loan to add more stock in preparation for the festive season.

Ernest's business is located in a busy market in the town thus many customers,  so extra profits. Ernest intends to open another shop within the town, and he hopes to become a prominent businessman.

loans.use: Purchase more clothes to sell for the festive season

loans.name: Roza's Group

texts.en:
Roza I. is the leader of this group. She is 63 and married. Together with her husband, who is already a pensioner, she has raised five children; all of them live separately from their parents and make their living on their own. The eldest son works for “Gazprom” company; one daughter is an employee of a bank, and two other daughters are students. Roza and her spouse earn income from cattle breeding. 16 years ago, having bought two calves, they decided to start their own business. Now they keep four animals. The loan purpose is to purchase more cattle to expand their herd. Any remainder of the money is intended to be spent for obtaining furniture for their daughter’s dowry. In future the family hopes to increase their herd up to 10 animals.

Roza’s partners:

Balbubu M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 42 and married. Her family has five children. Balbubu earns a living by working as a charwoman at school, and besides that, she is engaged in cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to buy foodstuffs. In future she wants to purchase a calf. 

Ainura S., 33, is married. Together with her husband, she is raising three children. Now, after having finished building a shop, the family wants to sell everyday necessities, and for this purpose they need to get a loan. 

Kalicha I., 51, is married. Her family has three children. The family makes their livelihood by farming. The loan purpose is to purchase coal for the winter. Then Kalicha wants to expand her herd of cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Sabira's Group

texts.en:
Sabira S. is the leader of this group. She is 41 and married. Together with her spouse, who works as a driver, she has three daughters; the eldest is married, the second one is a student, and the youngest - a schoolgirl. The family earns extra money by cattle breeding and milk selling. Out of their profits they have so far managed to pay for their daughter’s studies. In order to give their daughter a proper education, the family needs to obtain a loan. In future Sabira is planning to build a shed. 

Sabira’s partners:

Aizat A., 32, is married. Her family has three children. Following her sister’s advice, Aizat decided to start her business in cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase winter clothes. 

Gulzira I. is the treasurer of the group. She is 26 and married. Together with her husband she is bringing up one son. Gulzira earns a living by working as a hairdresser, and besides that, her family is engaged in cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase two calves to expand their herd. 

Aizada I., 34, is married. She is currently a housewife raising three children. Aizada’s husband supports the family financially by working in militia station. Their loan purpose is to purchase winter clothes. In future the family aims to obtain a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for their daughter's education

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase mobile phone accessories and repair tools

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert S. was born in 1978. He lives in Ijevan city with his wife and his parents. 

Robert runs his own clothing sales business in the Ijevan central market. He sells men's clothes: suits, trousers, sweaters and tracksuits. Thanks to his business income, Robert supports his family, and he says his parents help him a lot in his business. When he goes to purchase merchandise, his parents take his place at the business stall.  

Now Robert is asking for 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy outerwear to resell.

loans.use: To buy outerwear to resell

loans.name: Wan Word Women Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Wan Word Movement” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 400,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Kadiatu N. K. is the leader of this group. The forty-year-old is married to a trader and they have two children. Kadiatu sells palm wine and cigarettes. With her share of the loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil to sell.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For car maintenance

loans.name: John Macharia

texts.en:
John has practiced farming in Olkalou town since 1990.  He is 43 years old, married to Alice Wanjiri, and they have two children. He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to plant carrots and snow peas.

In future, John hopes to buy his own piece of land and save on the amount he uses to rent a farm every  planting season.

loans.use: To plant carrots and snow peas in his farm

loans.name: Maslandeneh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Maslandeneh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Baby M.. Baby is aged thirty-seven and she was born in Matotoka village. She is married with four children. Her husband is a trader and her children are attending primary and secondary schools.  For many years now, Baby has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), and ready-to-wear-clothes. With her share of this loan, she will buy clothes, undervests, etc. in large quantity. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buys clothes, undervests, etc. in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry farming

loans.name: Turganbubu

texts.en:
Turganbubu K. is 49, married, and has three grown children. In 1990, in order to support her family, she began her business in cattle breeding.   Currently, she has a barn and three cows, twenty sheep and one goat at her farm. In summer, she pastures her livestock in mountainous areas with natural grasses, which leads to reduced expenses.  With the revenue from this activity,  Turganbubu managed to give a good education to her children.  Now, Turganbubu plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to purchase three bull calves.  Using the revenue, she plans to give a dowry to her daughter. 

In future, Turganbubu plans to build a house for her family.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Reem

texts.en:
Reem is a young woman from Deir Al-Balah in Gaza Strip. She comes from a decent family. Reem wanted to start her own business after finishing school so, one year ago, she rented a small space and started a beauty salon offering services to her friends, neighbors and women of the area. Reem wants to expand her salon and serve a larger number of customers, especially now that the salon has started to prosper. She wants to help her parents pay the house rent. Reem came to Kiva's partner, FATEN, asking for a loan to purchase makeup and the beauty accessories she needs.

Reem appears in the photo.

About Shariah-compliant lending:
 
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To purchase makeup and beauty tools and materials

loans.name: Magbontho Group

texts.en:
Aminata S. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Aminata was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is age thirty-seven, married to a miner, and the couple has two children, both of whom are still attending secondary school. 

For over fifteen years now, Aminata has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), groundnuts, rice,  etc. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. Aminata will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business; she will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice to add to her current stock.  

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Elizabeth Adjoa Adjeiwa

texts.en: Elizabeth Adjoa Adjeiwa A. sells smoked and fried fish at Abura.  Elizabeth has junior high educational background. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. The loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to reinvest her additional income.

loans.use: buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul has a mixed farm in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya, that produces maize, potatoes, cabbages, milk, and coffee. He sells his products to the local market and through cooperative societies. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last twenty years. His primary challenges have been lack of organized markets for his products, pests and diseases, and low product prices.

Paul is 56 years old. He is married with six adult children. His youngest child is currently attending school.

Paul has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo and has successfully repaid his second loan of 55,000 KES. He has requested this loan of 85,000 KES to expand his banana farming. The increased income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his child in college and improve the family's livelihood. He comments that he is happy with Juhudi's policies which are geared towards helping small-holder farmers.

loans.use: To expand his banana farming.

loans.name: Elizabeth Aba Egyirba

texts.en: Elizabeth Aba Egyirba A. is single. She has no educational background. She sells cloth at Abura. She has been in the cloth business for three years now. Elizabeth uses her income to take care of herself. The loan will serve as additional working capital to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: additional working capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate a barber shop by painting and decorating

loans.name: Larkoh United Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Larkoh United” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Yayah Larkoh. Yayah is aged forty-four and he was born in Magburaka. He is married. Yayah is a lorry driver and a businessman. He sells palm oil, groundnuts, shoes, clothes, etc. With his share of this loan, he will buy the above mentioned items to sell and will also buy spare parts for his motorcar

loans.use: buy palm oil, groundnuts, shoes, clothes, etc., and also spare parts

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa A. sells oranges. She is also a stone cracker at Asenadze near Abura. She is married to a security man and has eight dependents. She assists her husband in providing for the basic needs of the family. The loan will be added to her initial capital to expand her business. She hopes to further her children’s education with the new profit.

loans.use: added to her initial capital to expand her business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a farmer in Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for twenty years. Her mixed farm produces milk, maize, beans and vegetables which she sells locally. She depends on the income from her farm to cater for the needs of her family. Her biggest challenges have been price fluctuation and diseases which affect her production. 

Jane is 43 years old. She is married with six children who all attend school.

Jane successfully repaid her fifth loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 71,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and expand her poultry project. The extra income from these projects will enable her see her children through school and also provide some little luxury. In future, she would like to venture into zero-grazing farming so that her animals can be well taken care of and increase production.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and expand her poultry project.

loans.name: Agartha Adjoa Boadzi

texts.en: Agartha Adjoa Boadzi O. is married to a mason and has four children. She has received junior high education.  Agartha sells ripe plantains, salt, salted fish and other items at Abura. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Agartha is asking to use the loan to buy additional foodstuffs, thus expanding her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agartha plans to build a house.

loans.use: buy additional foodstuffs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy soaps, torch-lights, biscuits, toothpaste, etc. in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a large amount of aluminium

loans.name: John Muriithi

texts.en:
John has practiced farming in Olkalou town since 1987. He is 61 years old, married to Monicah Waithera, and they have six children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan. He repaid his previous loans in good time, and plans to use this loan to plant potatoes on his farm.

In future, John hopes to buy another piece of land and start large-scale farming.

loans.use: To plant potatoes on his farm.

loans.name: Comfort Abena

texts.en: Comfort Abena A. cracks stones and sells them at Asenadze near Abura. She is divorced and has four children. Comfort has been selling stones for ten years. She sees to the well-being of her children. Her loan will be used to buy more stones to crack for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to further her children’s education.

loans.use: buy more stones to crack for sale

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is twenty-two years old and single. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for five years. His mixed farm produces maize, beans, and eggs which are all sold locally. He also owns and operates a food kiosk and a butchery in the same region. 

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES to expand his poultry farming. The extra income from this project will enable him to expand his business. He faces the challenge of losses due to poultry diseases. He hopes to venture into dairy farming in future and expand his poultry project.

loans.use: To expand his poultry farming.

loans.name: Mercy Efua Adgeiwa

texts.en: Mercy Efua Adgeiwa E. is married and has three children. She has attained junior high level of education. She sells costume jewelry at Abura. Mercy assists her husband in the upkeep of the home. The loan will enable her to purchase more jewelry and other items which are very often requested by her customers. Mercy plans to reinvest her additional revenue back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more costume jewelry and other items

loans.name: Beatrice Wanjiku

texts.en:
Beatrice has been selling motor vehicle spare parts in Olkalou town for the last five years. She is 32 years old, married to John Ndegwa, and they have four children.

She heard about KADET from one of our staff and this will be her third loan. She repaid her previous two loans in good time. She plans to increase her iventory of spare parts in her shop.

In future, Beatrice hopes to start supplying spare parts wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Jenefer Nana Ama Ampomah

texts.en:
Jenefer Nana Ama Ampomah D. is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. She has senior high educational background. Jenefer sells pastries at Asenadze near Abura. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She is asking for the loan to enable her to expand her business. Janefer hopes to reinvest her additional income.

In this photo, Jenefer is showing the flour and oil she uses for her pastries.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Shairbubu

texts.en:
Shairbubu K. is 53 years old and married.  She has four children and also is responsible for three children of her deceased brother-in-law.  

Shairbubu graduated from college and worked at the local kindergarten as a nurse.  In order to find a means of subsistence for her large family, in 1995 she began to breed livestock.  Her persistent and hard work allowed Shairbubu to maintain a farm with one cow, eight sheep, and two goats.  With the revenue from this activity, she was able to pay for education for her daughters.  

Currently, Shairbubu is applying for a loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to purchase three calves. Using the revenues from this loan, she plans to marry off her son and build a house for him. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Salamatu Ama Mansa

texts.en: Salamatu Ama Mansa I. is married and has seven dependents. She has no educational background. Salamatu sells pastries at Abura. She has been in this trade for seven years. Her husband is a mason. Salamatu uses her income to assist her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her dependents. She is asking for the loan to buy more ingredients to prepare pastries for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Salamatu plans to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: buy more ingredients to prepare pastries

loans.name: Kai A.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Micronfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you teachers of the R.C Musaia primary school near Kabala town. This school was founded in 1954 to educate the children of Mosaia village. Today, the school is staffed with eight teachers and has 450 pupils. This school is proud itself as the most organised, clean school, with an up-to-date record keeping system - an award given to the school by UNICEF.

Staff from various schools and other government offices within SMT's operational areas come to SMT to seek loans. At the end of each month, these institutions' bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment from their salaries and pays SMT on their behalf. With the help of these loans, these teachers can do or buy things that their mere salaries alone can not do or buy. 

The leader of this group of teachers is Kai A. G.. The fifty-year-old Kai was born in Kono, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. He is married and has seven children who are attending school. Mr. G. is going to use his share of this loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane O. is 37 years old, married, and has seven children, all of whom  attend school.  She has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years in Kitale town, western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, tea, and tomatoes which are all sold locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater to the needs of her family. 

Jane has requested a loan of 20,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that her family will be guaranteed enough milk for consumption from the dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will help for school fees for her children. Her primary challenges have been diseases, which affect her production, and lack of funds to expand her farming. She would like to acquire three dairy cows in five years' time and expand her farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Teresiah Njeri

texts.en:
Teresiah has been operating her beauty salon in Olkalou town for the last 12 years.  She is 48 years old, married to David N., and they have three children.

She heard about KADET from a KADET field officer.  This will be her first loan and she plans to use the loan to buy a new hair dryer for her beauty salon.

In future, Teresiah hopes to expand her beauty salon so that it can serve many clients at once.

loans.use: To buy a new hair dryer

loans.name: Mary Wangui

texts.en:
Mary has operated her retail shop in Olkalou town for the last 10 years.  She also practices farming on the side to boost her income.  She is 41 years old, a single mother of one child.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and potato seedlings for her farm.

In future, Mary plans to move to the transport sector and buy her own lorry which she will use for transporting goods from the farms to the market.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and potato seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Dorila

texts.es:
DORILA I. P.
La señora Dorila socia del banco comunal Pan de Vida. Del distrito de Manantay  departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años, 4 hijos uno independiente y  tres menores a su cargo, su esposo es empleado público.
La señora Dorila lleva 4 años trabajando con los préstamos de  Manuela Ramos, anteriormente ha estado criando pollos. Actualmente tiene una bodega en su casa, al cual se dedica todo el día que también le permite atender a sus hijos menores.
Con su nuevo préstamo  de  S/. 1,500.00 soles,  lo invertirá en la compra de: 1 caja de  aceite, 1 paquete de sal, 2 cajas de galleta soda, 1 caja de galleta vainilla, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 3 paquetes de papel higiénico, 1 caja de leche chica, 1 caja de leche grande, condimentos, ½  bolsa de lejía, 2 bolsas de caramelo, 3 casilleros de huevo, 10 kilos de papas, 3 kg de cebolla, 1 kg de ajos, 3 kg de tomate.
 La señora Dorila con su negocio más el sueldo de su esposo les alcanza para seguir educando a sus hijos y pagar sus servicios básicos, por eso esta más que agradecida con Manuela Ramos y espera que sigan apoyando a todas las mujeres que lo necesitan.
texts.en:
DORILA I. P.
Sra. Dorila, 50, is a member of the Pan de Vida community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali.  She has 4 grown children, who are independent, and 3 younger children, who still live at home.  Her husband is a public-sector worker.  Sra. Dorila has been a client of Manuela Ramos for 4 years.  Before that, she operated a business raising chickens.  Now she has a corner grocery that she operates from her house, a business that allows her to both earn an income and still take care of her younger children.  With this S/.1,500 [1,500 Peruvian soles] loan, she will buy bulk supplies of: cooking oil, salt, soda crackers, vanilla crackers, rice, sugar, toilet paper, milk, condiments, bleach, candy, eggs, potatoes, onions, garlic and tomatoes.  The earnings from Sra. Dorila's business, combined with her husband's income, just stretches to pay for their kid's schooling and their everyday living expenses.  She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for their support of her business and she hopes that the bank will go on supporting the women who need these loans.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Sesay United Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the "S. United" group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. For the very first time, these entrepreneurs have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to buy more goods to add to their respective business, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions.

The leader of this group is Foday S.. Mr. S. is a forty-five-year-old man who was born in the city of Bo, in southern Sierra Leone. He is today residing in Magburaka, together with his wife and two children. His wife is a school teacher and his children are attending secondary school. Mr. S. sells palm oil, rice, groundnuts, peppers, etc. He has been doing this business for many years now. With the help of this loan, he will be able to buy the above-mentioned items in bulk to add to his current inventory. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy palm oil, rice, groundnuts, peppers, etc. in bulk

loans.name: Nery

texts.es:
NERY V. A.
Nery socia del banco comunal  Pan de Vida. Del distrito de manantay  departamento de Ucayali,  tiene 47 años de edad casada, con 5 hijos menores en edad escolar.
 La señora Nery  viene trabajando  junto a su esposo que es técnico electricista en el taller de rebobinado de motores que tienen hace varios años, con los préstamos que hace de Manuela Ramos  han ido implementando su taller.
En horas de la mañana Nery se ocupa del cuidado de su hogar y de mandar al colegio a sus hijos, y llevar el almuerzo a su esposo, en horas de la tarde se encarga de las compras o de algún trámite que tengan que realizar.
Nery con el ultimo préstamo de S/. 1000.00 soles. Va invertir todo en su taller, comprara 2 rollos de alambre para rebobinados, cintas lo necesario, 1 rollo de cable, silicona.
Gracias a Manuela Ramos la señora Nery y su familia están surgiendo en su negocio, también están generando empleo porque tiene un trabajador a su cargo y más adelante piensan brindar servicio a domicilio.
texts.en:
Nery is a member of the 'Pan de Vida' (Bread of Life) community bank in the district of Manantay, in the department of Ucayali.  She is 47 years old, married and has 5 school-age children.

Nery works together with her husband who is an electrical technician in the motor winding workshop which they have had for several years.  They have been setting up their workshop with the loans they have received from Manuela Ramos.

In the morning, Nery takes care of the house, sees her children off to school and takes her husband his lunch.  In the afternoon she looks after sales and any paperwork which needs doing.

Nery will invest this loan for 1,000 nuevos soles in the workshop.  She will buy 2 rolls of wire, as much tape as necessary, one roll of cable and silicone adhesive.

Thanks to Manuela Ramos, Nery and her family are doing well in their business.  They are also creating work as they now employ a worker and in the future plan to provide a home delivery service.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Gibson

texts.en:
Gibson is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for five years. He has a mixed farm which produces maize, milk and beans which are all sold locally. He is also employed as a casual worker in the same region. His biggest challenges have been diseases which are too costly to treat and fluctuation in the market prices of produce.

Gibson is 30 years old. He is married with three children who are now between the ages of 18 months and 6 years old. Two of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested this loan of 34,320 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable him to meet the basic needs of his family. He hopes to purchase more dairy cows in future that will increase his productivity.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married man with two children. He is from Lebanon. He has owned his small vegetable store since 2000, and he has a previous experience of 20 years in this occupation. He sells all types of vegetables according to their availability during the season. He has obtained a first Kiva loan and today he is asking for a new loan of $1200 to increase his store’s inventory and to buy new stands to use to offer his products to the customers. He expects that his business will continue to grow in the coming year. 

It is very common in Lebanon to find small vegetables and fruit shops. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demand. The strong network of community relationships is an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in the smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: increase his store’s inventory and to buy new stands to use to offer his products to the customers

loans.name: Julia Lizett

texts.es:
JULIA LIZZET F. T.
La señora Julia socia del banco comunal Pan y Vida. Del distrito de Manantay, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 61 años de edad, madre soltera con 8 hijos mayores.
Julia se dedica a la confección de vestidos y ropas interiores desde hace muchos años, porque lo ha servido como sustento de su hogar, hace 2 años que viene trabajando con Manuela Ramos.
Con su primer préstamo julia compro otra máquina, porque el que tenía  le fallaba mucho y no podía cumplir con las costuras que tenia.
 Julia con su ultimo préstamo de S/. 1500.00 soles, lo invertirá en la compra  2 conos de elásticos, 5 metros de tela de algodón, 3 conos de hilo, blanco, negro, rojo, azul. 1/2 de ciento de papel molde. Blondas en varios colores, también comprara medio ciento de madera para arreglar parte de su pequeño taller.
Julia, contenta con lo que ha logrado hasta este momento, porque ha sacado adelante a su hijo autista que tiene a su cargo, gracias a  Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
JULIA LIZZET F. T.
Julia is a member of the Pan y Vida communal bank from the distrito of Manantay, departamento of Ucayali. She is 61 years old and s ingle mother of 8 grown children.  

Julia has made dresses and underclothing for many years. It has supported her home. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 2 years.
With her first loan, Julia bought another machine because the one she had was failing and she couldn't finish the sewing that she had. 

 Julia will invest her latest loan of S/. 1500.00 soles in the purchase of 2 rolls of elastic, 5 meters of cotton fabric, 3 rolls of white, black, red and blue thread and lace in various colors.  She will also buy wood to fix a part of her small workshop. Julia is happy with what she has acheived thus far, because she takes care of her autistic son and has gotten him ahead, thanks to Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To buy fabric and elastic

loans.name: Patrick Maingi

texts.en:
Patrick Maingi M. has been in the business of livestock trading for 10 years. He buys livestock, rears it, and  sells it later at a profit. He earns a profit of Kshs.40,000 per month.  He is 40 years old and married to Kanini, and together they have five children aged between 20 years and 10 years old. The business   location is in  Matuu and  he has many customers since his sales take place in the open air market in Matuu. 

M. has no history with any other MFI and he is applying for his third loan of Kshs. 40,000 from KADET LTD after paying back the previous loans successfully. The purpose for this loan is to buy four cows to rear and sell later at a profit. 


He plans to use the anticipated profit to educate his children and also provide for the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy four cows

loans.name: Clara Luz

texts.es:
CLARA LUZ T. C.
La señora clara pertenece al banco comunal El Paraíso. Distrito de manatay,   provincia de coronel portillo departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 67 años de edad, mujer sola que esta sobresaliendo en estos tiempos tan difíciles. Madre de 10 hijos ya con familia cada uno de ellos.
La señora clara viene trabajando con manuela ramos hace 12 años, el mismo tiempo que Tiene su negocio de venta de golosinas, el cual le ha servido como sustento todo este tiempo y lo va haciendo crecer con los préstamos que obtiene de Manuela Ramos cada ciclo.
Con el ultimo préstamo de  s/. 1500 soles que Manuela Ramos le otorgo  va surtir mas su negocio,  comprara  3 cajitas de frugos,  2 cajas de néctar,  una caja de galleta soda, una de vainilla , 5 cajas de gaseosa oro,  3 cajas de cola real, 1 caja de vasos descartables, una bolsa de halls  , 1 bolsa de caramelo de limón, una caja de lentejitas, 2 bolsas de chupetines, una caja de frunas,  2 tiras de maní confitado.
La señora clara está muy agradecida por los préstamo que manuela Ramos le da cada ciclo la forma que ella tiene de agradecerle es siendo puntual con sus pagos de cada mes.
texts.en:
Clara Luz T. C.
Clara belongs to the 'El Paraíso' (Paradise) community bank in Manatay, in Coronel Portillo province, in Ucayali department.  She is 67 years old.  She is a single woman who is doing well in these difficult times.  She is mother to 10 children, each of whom already has a family of their own.

Clara has been working with Manuela Ramos for 12 years, the same amount of time that she has had her business selling sweets.  The business has been a support for her all this time and she has been making it grow with the loans she obtains from Manuela Ramos.

She will use her latest loan from Manuela Ramos for 1,500 soles to better stock her store.  She will buy 3 small crates of Frugos yogurt, 2 crates of nectar, one box of soda (saltine) crackers, one of vanilla, 5 crates of Oro brand soda, 3 crates of Cola Real, 1 box of disposable cups, one bag of Halls, a bag of lemon drops, a box of Lentejitas (an M&M style candy), 2 bags of lollipops, a box of Frunas (Starburst style candies) and 2 boxes of Maní Confitado (a brand of sweetened peanuts).

Clara is very grateful for the loans which Manuela Ramos give her each cycle.  Her shows her gratitude by being punctual with her payments every month.

loans.use: Purchase of Frugos yogurt and soda

loans.name: Comfort Adjoa Brokuma

texts.en: Comfort Adjoa Brokuma M. is married and has a child. Her husband is a driver. She has received junior high education. Comfort sells plastic bowls at Abura. Her income is used to assist her husband in taking care of the family. Comfort will use the loan to purchase more plastic bowls for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort wishes to save towards her child’s education.

loans.use: purchase more plastic bowls for resale

loans.name: Mary Ekua Donkor

texts.en:
Mary Ekua Donkor O. is married and has three children. Her husband is an electrician. She sells cooked plantains and beans (a dish called "red-red") at Abura. She has been in this trade for two years. Mary assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will add the loan to her capital to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to buy a plot of land.

In this photograph, Mary is picking out the chaff from the beans.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old married woman with one child. She is from Lebanon. She has been working as a beautician since 2007. She works from her home and also as a traveler. This young woman works hard to help her husband to raise her little child. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase wholesale beauty products from a cosmetic company. In the future, she plans to open a formal beauty salon to offer her services to her clients and add new beauty services.

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women are able to serve as strong role models for their children while also helping to supplement their household incomes. In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.

loans.use: purchase beauty products wholesale

loans.name: Carlo

texts.en: This lady is 29 years old and married with three children who are in  school.  She has been operating a cyber café for three years.  Besides, she sells stationery and does printing.  She has learnt how to manage her business through Faulu Kenya.  In her business, she has employed one person.  She hopes to open an information bureau in five years.  She has requested a loan of 60,000 Kes.  She will use the loan to buy a computer and stationery.

loans.use: To buy a computer and stationery

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en: Jolly owns and runs Jolly Enterprises, a photo studio.  He has been able to employ two people.  He has been running his business for thirteen years.  He also works as a house agent so as to earn an extra income.  He hopes to open an outlet for his business in the future.  He has been guaranteed a loan of 80,000 Kes by his group members in Faulu Kenya.  He will use the loan to buy a digital camera and decorations for his business premises.

loans.use: To buy a digital camera and decorations for his business premises

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es: Bertha, D. 59 años, es una madre D. familia D. buen carácter, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo y sus 5 hijos que son varones, quienes trabajan en el transporte público. Hace más D. 14 años  trabaja con su esposo, brindando servicio D. transporte público. Inicialmente ella era la cobradora y su esposo el chofer, pero por un tiempo le fue muy bien. Actualmente sus hijos han tomado la posta, desD. entonces Bertha se dedica a la preparación D. menú diario y también en la administración del servicio D. transporte, así como hacer los pedidos  D. repuestos para sus vehículos. Le gusta mucho el trabajo que tiene, ya que le es rentable y D. las ganancias se compraron un segundo carro, para que sus hijos puedan trabajar y sean independientes. Por lo pronto continuará construyendo su casa, ya que su fin es alquilarlo. Es su crédito número 16 con MFP, sabe que el crédito que recibe le será muy beneficioso para la reparación D. su carro; además, comenta que le gusta ser puntual en las reuniones D. su banco comunal. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará algunos repuestos D. su carro, para que trabaje sin desperfectos en sus vehículos.
texts.en: Bertha is 59 years old. She is a wife and mother of good character. She lives in her own house wit hher husband nad 5 sons. They work an public transport. She has worked with her  husband for more than 14 years offering public transport service. At first she took the money and her husband drove, but for a time it went very well. Now her sons have taken over her post and Bertha prepares the daily menu and and manages the transportation service and makes the orders for the vehicle replacement parts. She really likes her job since it is profitable and with the earnings they bought a second car so that her sons can work and be independent. Soon she will continue building her house, since the idea is to rent it out. This is her 16th loan with MFP. She knows that the loan she receives will be very beneficial for car repair, so she can work without imperfections in her vehicles.

loans.use: To buy replacement parts for her vehicle

loans.name: Wilber Javier

texts.es: Wilber Javier tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación. Hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio. Pues busca la forma de mejorar los ingresos de su familia. Su actividad es una pulpería, que inicia desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche, por lo que la mayoría de sus clientes llegan a buscar sus diferentes productos inicio por una herencia de su abuelo y quería sacar adelante este negocio que sería la fuente de ingresos necesarios para mantener a sus 2 hijos y mantener esta actividad. El crédito será invertido en la compra de materia prima para su negocio.
texts.en:
Wilber Javier has worked with the Fundación for a long time.  He has worked in this business for over seven years.  He looks for the way to improve the family income.  He has a grocery store.  He starts at seven in the morning and works until ten at night.

Most of his customers come to the store to look for his different products.  He started with an inheritance from his grandfather.  He wanted to get this business ahead as it would be the needed source of income to support his two children and stay in the business.

The loan will be used to buy supplies for his business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Alfredo Jose

texts.es: Alfredo José tiene 37 años. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Pues hace mas de 6 años que se dedica esta actividad. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos. Inicio por su Padre ya que él no podía seguir adelante con este negocio y Alfredo tenia los conocimientos para administrar este negocio es así como el se hace cargo de administrarlo y proporcionar lo necesario. Estos son los motivos que solicita este crédito con el fin de comprar productos como calzado, perfumes, cosméticos, cremas y otras cosas que le han solicitado.
texts.en:
Alfredo José is 37 years old.  He has been selling general merchandise for over six years.  This is not his first loan.

He started because his father could no longer continue on with the business.  Alfredo knew how to run the business, and that is how he took charge of running the business and providing it with the necessities.

That is why he is requesting this loan to buy products like footwear, perfume, cosmetics, creams, and other items that have been requested.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi M. is married and has four children. Her husband is a messenger. She has been through junior high school.  Esi sells cooking utensils and meat at Abura. Esi assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She is requesting the loan to use  to purchase different varieties of meat for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase different sorts of meat for sale

loans.name: Erika

texts.es: Erika, de 35 años, es madre soltera, tiene 4 hijos y juntos viven en casa de su madre. Durante la semana trabaja como en una fábrica de textiles colocando etiquetas a las prendas, pero los fines de semana se dedica a vender tamales, es así que cada viernes luego de la jornada laboral, lo que resta del día hasta altas horas de la noche prepara el maíz y los convierte en ricos tamales. Desde hace 6 años realiza la misma rutina, siendo éste paltillo vendido en el puesto de venta de comida de su madre. Esta muy contenta por su negocio, por lo que puede captar buenas utilidades para el bienestar de sus hijos, quienes son su mayor adoración. Más adelante  anhela instalar un restaurante en sociedad con su mamá. Es su 16avo crédito con MFP, sabe que éste aporte le será muy beneficioso para el desarrollo de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, es para comprar utensilios de cocina.
texts.en:
Erika, age 35, is a single mother.  She has four children, and they live together in her mother’s house.  During the week she works in a textile factory placing labels on clothes.  On the week-ends she sells tamales.  

Every Friday she spends the time after work until very late at night preparing the corn and then making the delicious tamales.  She has been following this same routine for six years.  This is the dish that is sold at her mother’s food stand.

She is very happy with her business because she is able to get good income for her children’s well-being.  Her children are her greatest love.

This is her 16th loan with MFP.  She knows that this help with be of great benefit in the development of her business.  She will use the requested loan to buy cooking utensils.

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en: Sheila is a member of 'Diamond Women' group in Faulu Kenya.  To make a living, she sells clothes.  She has been in the business for one year.
