Dina is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Dina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon P. is from the village of San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 53 years old and married, with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Corazon  buys and sells sweet bananas. Corazon has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

Corazon joined HSPFI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon is requesting her first loan, for 5000 PHP, to be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory; to add to working capitall

location.town: San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Srun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has six members who live in Kaoh Touch village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Srun Y. is a group leader who has been selected by the other members who will each use their loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Pruonh Nhoem, are farmers who own more two-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell and support their family. This is the growing season but she does not have enough money to support the business. To improve this farming business, Mrs. Srun Y. is asking for a loan to purchase bean seed, pesticide, and gasoline. She has two children, one of whom is attending in school, and the other is too young to work or study. 

The day of the loan disbursement Mrs. Srun Y. was busy working in the field. Her husband, Mr. Pruonh Nhoem, received the loan for her. The photo above is of Mrs. Srun Y.'s husband.

loans.use: To purchase bean seed, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Analisa

texts.en:
Analisa R. is from the village of Villa Sudiacal, Baybay Liloy, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 43 years old. Analisa is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Analisa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Analisa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Analisa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Analisa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Villa Sudiacal, Liloy, ZAmboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Dionesio

texts.en:
Dionesio D. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. He is 39 years old. Dionesio is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Dionesio owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from fishing and selling fish like milkfish, mackerel and also shrimps in the local community. Dionesio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dionesio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dionesio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new tools for the maintenance of the boat. Dionesio is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Dionesio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Lun's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine members. They are located in Peam Reang Kraom village, Kandal province. This village members selected Mrs. Lun S. as the village bank president. Each members will use their portion of the loan with different purposes. 

Mrs. Lun S. and her husband, Mr. Vann Saratt, are farmers who own 1-hectare of land to cultivate corn and peanuts. With their farming, they face a problem. They do not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. Thus, Mrs. Lun S. would like to ask for a loan to buy corn seeds, peanut seeds, and fertilizers and pesticides to strengthen the business. Beside being a farmer, Mrs. Lun S. is also sells Khmer cake in the local market and is able to earn some additional profit to support the family. This couple has three children. Two are students in the local school and also help their parents business, while another is just 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy corn seed, peanut seed, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Him's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Him Y., she is a bank group leader who has been selected by four members whom live in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family standard living.

Mrs. Him Y., was born in 1957. She is a widow who has no children.  She is a pig breeder who earns money to support her family. Since her business is going well time at this time, she wants to expand but she did not have enough working capital. So, to improve this business, Mrs. Him Y. is seeking a loan to buy more pigs.

loans.use: To buy more pigs

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy G. is from the village of Bal-ason, Gingoog City. She is 40 years old. Juvy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, biscuits, junk foods and instant noodles in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $200 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Chum's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four members who live in Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chum C., 32 years old, is the group leader who was selected by the other members. They are going to buy something that relates to their businesses. She rents a general store and sells groceries near the garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Phorlla Nhem, works in the garment factory. In order to improve the family, she wants to start a new business. Thus, Mrs. Chum C. is requesting a loan to buy more coffee to sell. She has a child who is helping her in her business.

loans.use: To buy more coffee to make coffee for sell

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en:
Yoem C., 36, is a villager who lives in Kompong Tom Province. She and her husband (pictured in the photo) have a business of purchasing, at low cost, hair from women who have long hair, and reselling it at a profit to hairdressers and other salon shops in their community. They are blessed with one young child who is not yet enrolled in school. 

Yoem C. wishes to enlarge her business and is applying for a loan to purchase more hair to sell. This will allow her to increase her income to ensure that her entire family attains a good standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more hair to sell.

loans.name: Phall

texts.en: Mrs. Phall S. is a villager in Krabau village in Kandal province and she was born in 1977. She and her husband, Mr. Ven Tang, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow vegetables to sell to support their family. She has a problem because her field has infertile soil, but she does not have enough money to support it. So, to improve this field, Mrs. Phall S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. This couple has three children, two of whom are studying in school, and the other is two years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina is a hardworking lady. She stitches footballs to financially support her family. She receives the orders from football manufacturing factories. Those factories provide her with raw materials and she provides them with the finished product. In this way, she generates income for her family. She lives with her family in Gujranwala, which is a well known industrial city of Pakistan. Her house is located in the area named Veniawala. She is the mother of two sons, neither of whom are of school going age.

She is married to Z. A. who has a welding shop. He welds iron items on order. His shop is in the market and making him a reasonable income every month. He has been doing this business for over twenty years. 

Samina has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another welding machine which will help him to work more efficiently and in a better way. She is hopeful that through this investment her husband’s business will definitely grow. 
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client who always paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy another welding machine for welding business

loans.name: Iem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Iem K. was born in 1968 and she lives in Khsach village in Kandal province. She is the group leader who has been selected by the members in this group loan. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. 

Now, she has problem because it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough rice seed. So, to improve this farm, Mrs. Iem K. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed. 

Her husband, Mr. Hout Ket, is a television repairman who can earn some money to support his family, too. She is the mother of four children who are all students, and besides this they help in their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Kit's Group

texts.en:
Twenty-four people make up this village loan. They are located in Pou Thum village in Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Kit C. as the village bank president. The members will each use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Kit C. and her husband, Mr. Praom Kimsan, are farmers who own one-hectare of land that they use to cultivate corn and vegetables for a living. For this farm, C. would like to ask for a loan to buy vegetable seed and corn seed to support her farming. She works very hard to support their two children, one of whom works in a restaurant and the other attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed and corn seed to support her farming

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Girlie P. is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  making fresh noodles and copra (dried coconut). She lives in Park Republic, Barangay 4, Roxas, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $663. 

Girlie is borrowing 19,000 PHP so that she can purchase raw materials for her noodle production business. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Girlie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make into fresh noodles

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a resident of Gujranwala, which is a big industrial city in Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house in the area named Veniawala and lives in it with her family.  She is an active lady who carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and takes care of her children. She is married to A. who has a grocery store business. 

She is the mother of three sons. Her first two sons are involved in different businesses. Her eldest son has a welding shop and the next oldest is running a computer hardware shop through which he sells computer parts. Her youngest son is 18 years old and stays at home because he is currently jobless. 

Razia has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her elder son’s welding business. He will invest the loan in the purchase of another welding machine that will help him do his work better and produce quality work. Razia is hopeful that, after this investment, her son will be able to improve his business, resulting in financial stability for the family. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah. In the photo, Razia is the lady who has a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands.

loans.use: To buy another welding machine for her son's welding business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda F. is 47 years old, married, and lives in Antipolo, Rizal, in the Philippines with her husband and her two daughters, Cyrel and Nicole.  To supply additional income for her family, Yolanda is opening a business of buying and selling a variety of small goods in her neighborhood.

Yolanda would like to receive a loan amounting 10,000 PHP to support her venture.  She believes this loan will help her business attract more customers.  This is the first year of her membership in Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines. Yolanda is grateful for the access to loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams.

Her long term goals are to have a successful business, to have her own house, to fund the education of her siblings until they complete a degree and to support her family financially.  With the support of ASHI, Yolanda is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor.

loans.use: to support her buying and selling business

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
Mrs. Bin C., a widow in Preaek Touch village in Kandal Province, has four children, two of whom are farmers, another a seamstress in a garment factory, and another who assists her in selling groceries. A farmer who owns a small piece of land upon which she cultivates rice to support her family, Bin also owns a general store in the local village.

This is the season to grow rice, but due to a lack of funds, Bin is requesting a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer, with the rest of the loan to be used to buy more groceries and fix the motorbike.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Jusima

texts.en:
Jusima P., a widow who lives in Sitio Bombon, Pinamungajan, Cebu, earns her living by operating two ventures: food vending and sari-sari (general) store businesses. She has five children between the ages of 30 and 39.

Jusima joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jusima has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 11000 to use as additional working capital for her food vending and sari-sari store businesses so that she can continue to save for her future security and to help her grandson finish school. Jusima P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia B., 58, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines, is married to Rodolfo B., a farmer and her business partner. A mother of five young hardworking adults, by the grace of God Aurelia has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Aurelia operates a greenhouse where she grows ornamental plants and fruits and vegetables. Ornamental plants are mostly needed by landscape artists, while fruits and vegetables are staples in every community market. Aurelia manages the finances and sales of the greenhouse while her husband cultivates the plants.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan to buy more supplies needed for the greenhouse, including fertilizers, and to pay wages for their farm workers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

As a result of all of her work with the business, Aurelia hopes to renovate her house soon, She also dreams of an abundant life while enjoying the good health of her entire family. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Each fellowship group, composed of 15 to 30 community partners, gathers each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies such as fertilizers and pay wages for farm workers

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia C., a 48-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari store, lives in Prk. Santol, QCRO, Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 30000.

Emelia is requesting a loan of PHP 19000 to add to her working capital in order to purchase more products to sell in her store. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Emelia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a community member who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nat C. is a 32-year-old married woman selected as the village bank president of this 24-member group. Located in Pou Thum village in Kandal Province, the members of this village loan will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their various purposes.

Nat earns her living by selling groceries in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and so is requesting a loan to buy more groceries. Her husband, Mr. Him Sokha, 34 years old, works as construction worker. With their occupations, they are able to earn a little income to support their famiL. which consists of three children, all students in the local school and also helpers in their mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Nasira's Group

texts.en:
Nasira is married to M. H.. She is 33 years old and has been living in Gujranwala, Pakistan for many years. Gujranwala is an industrial city also known for its rice crops. She does stitching work to bear the financial burden with her husband. She receives orders from her neighboring areas and fills the order on time to earn income for the family. 

Her husband is a private entrepreneur and involved in a food-selling business. He sells a dish named "Gol Gapay" which is very famous among people here. It has a round shape and is made with flour and served with chilly sauces and yogurt. Because of its spicy taste people loves to eat it.  He visits different streets of the city with his four-wheeled cart to sell the food. Nasira also helps her husband in preparing the dish so he sells a good quantity every day. 

Nasira is a mother of 4 sons. Two of them are enrolled in school while the other two stay at home. Nasira wants to provide education to her remaining two sons also for which reason she works very hard along with her husband. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. He will invest the loan in purchasing required items such as spices, cooking oil, yogurt and flour in bulk quantity to improve his sales. He has been doing this business for over 20 years and Nasira is hopeful that this investment will bring more profit for her husband. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she has built up a good credit record and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Nasira.

loans.use: To buy required items for food dish (Gol Gapay)

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is twenty-six years old. He is married and has been blessed with three children who are between the ages of 3 and 8. Two of the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for five years. His farm currently produces milk and tomatoes which he sells at the local market. He also earns income from his battery charging business. 

Moses has requested this loan of 31,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to purchase a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable him to send his children to better schools. His biggest challenge has been the lack of enough animal feed especially during the dry season. He hopes that in the next five years he will be able to acquire five dairy cows and a chuff cutter (to cut fodder for them).

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Nhoel's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four members who live in Preaek Touch village in Kandal province. All the members have selected Mrs. Nhoel S. is the group leader. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living conditions. 

Mrs. Nhoel S. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to use to grow rice to sell to support her family. Now she has a problem because it is time to grow rice in her field but she does not have rice seed and fertilizer. So, to improve her field, Mrs. Nhoel S. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer. With any remainder of this loan she is going to hire farming laborers and oxen to plow her field. She is a widow with two children who are laborers.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer

loans.name: Anayat's Group

texts.en:
Anayat is a widow. She lost her husband few years ago as a result of sudden death. It was a very difficult time for her but she never lost hope and started sewing work to be able to afford the expenses of her children. She has raised her children with great care. 

Now her children are young men and do their business. She has two sons and both have a shop of automobile spare parts. They have a shop in the market where they deal with their customers and fill their need for spare parts.   Anayat now stays at home and takes care of her household responsibilities and of her sons. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sons' business. They will invest the loan in purchasing spare parts for different vehicles. The availability of stock will help them to fulfill the requirements of their customers in a timely manner which will result in good earnings.  They started this business a few years ago and Anayat is hopeful that her sons will successfully be able to improve their business with the help of this loan investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained her good credit behavior and attended every meeting.  

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Anayat.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her sons' business

loans.name: Put

texts.en:
Mrs. Put S. is a married woman who lives in Kandal village in Kandal province. She was born in 1959. She and her husband, Mr. Hung Some Koem, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow rice and corn to sell to market in order to support their family. 

In her field,it now is infertile which it affects to her crops. To improve her crop productivity, Mrs. Put S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. 

She is the mother of a child who is a television repairer. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Mrs. Chum R. is a vegetable seller who is 55 and is a married mother caring for four children, three of whom are single while the remaining one is married. All of them are employed in various jobs.

 Mrs. Chum R. has been selling vegetables for years in the busy market, and her business is running well because she sells her items at a reasonable cost to all customers. Her husband is a local farmer in the province of Kompong Tom. Because she has been occupied with her business, Mrs. Chum R. hasn't plowed her farmland yet. To solve this problem, Mrs. Chum R. is applying for a loan to hire a machine to plow the farmland. With the rest of the loan she will buy some vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To hire a machine to plow farmland and  buy some vegetable to sell

loans.name: Chhen Tei Group Loan

texts.en:
Sixteen people make up this village bank loA.. They are located in Veal Thum village in Kandal province. This village members selected Mrs. Chhen T., 39 and a married womA., as the village bank president. With their loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their families' living conditions.
 
Mrs. Chhen T. earns her living by selling soup noodle in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loA. to buy more soup noodle supplies to enlarge her business activities. 

Her husband, Mr. Choeun S., 40, works as a police officer, and he also helps his wife in this business. They have five children four if whom are students in the local school while the other is just 3 years old which is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more soup noodle  supplies

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for eight years and employs one farmhand. His farm produces wheat, maize, vegetables, bananas and tea which are all sold locally. He also earns income from his lumbering business in the same location. His primary challenge in farming has been unfavorable weather conditions which affects his production. 

He has requested this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him expand his farm and improve the livelihood of his family.

Ronald is 28 years old. He is married with four children who are between the ages of 2 and 6. Two of the children are currently attending school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Ret Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has twenty-six people who live in Preaek Ta Ong Ti Muoy village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sok R. is the village bank president and her age is 62. She has been selected by the other members who will each use their loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Nguon Khut, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they grow rice,  not to sell but to support their family. She is also a mat weaver while her husband is a construction worker. 

She faces a problem because it is time to grow crops on her field but she does not have money to support the crops. So, to improve production, Mrs. Sok R. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed and gasoline. With any remainder of the loan she is going to hire farming laborers and oxen to plow her field. Through this activity they support three children, two of whom are employed in an organization, while the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and gasoline

loans.name: Mrs. Sem Chansok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up a village bank loan located in Tuol Tnaot village in Kandal province and have selected Mrs. Sem C., born in 1979. as the village bank president. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes which can improve their families' living conditions. 

Mrs. Sem C. is a married woman who has three children, one of whom is enrolled in a local school, while the others are too young to work or study. She is a Khmer cake maker who can earn some money in this way to support her family. Since her business is presently going well,  she wants to expand. So, to meet this goal, Mrs. Sem C. is applying for a loan to buy more corn, coconuts, sugar, and rice to make Khmer cake to sell. Her husband, Mr. Sokorn Suon, is a motorbike taxi driver who is able to earn some money to support his family, too.

loans.use: To buy more corn, coconuts, sugar, and rice to make Khmer cake to sell

loans.name: My

texts.en:
Mrs. My K. is a 38-year-old married woman and a local farmer in Kompong Tom province. She uses her farmland to plant and grow rice and vegetable crops. Mrs. My K. has two children, one is single and the other works as a building worker with her husband in the construction field. She usually receives the main income from her husband and child.
Mrs. My K. is concerned about the difficulties her husband and child face in traveling to their workplace. They have to hire a taxi because they don't have their own vehicle. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. My K. has requested a loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle to provide her family with a means of transport.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle for her family

loans.name: Mr. Saom Sarun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 17 people who live in Kong Noy village in Kandal province. Mr. Saom S. is the village bank president who has beE. selected by the other members. The group members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes.
Mr. Saom S. is a 50-year-old farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare plot of land to grow rice to sell yearly to support his family. At present he has a problem because it is time to grow rice but he does not have enough money to do this. Therefore, Mr. Saom S. is requesting a loan to continue farming this current year. His wife, Mrs. S. Art Horm, is a teacher in a local school and earns a low salary to support her family. The couple supports five childrE. – one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, and the others are studying in a local public school.

loans.use: To farm rice this year

loans.name: Soung

texts.en:
Soung Y. is a 49-year-old widowed villager who lives in Kompong Tom province. She is the mother of only one child who is studying in high school. Her husband died of senility years ago.
Soung Y. has been in the farming business for years. She has also built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn more income for family expenses. Since the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for her, Soung Y. has requested a loan in order to buy additional pigs to raise for sale during the period when pork is commanding a high price.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 38 years old, married and blessed with four children aged between 2 and 11. Three of his children are currently attending school.
Samuel has a mixed farm in Nyamira town, western Kenya, that produces bananas, napier grass, maize, beans and milk. He sells all his products to the local market. He has been farming for ten years and employs one farmhand. He also earns income from his hotel business in the same location. He says that his biggest challenge in farming has been the pests and diseases that affect his crops.
Samuel has requested this loan of 45,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help him pay his children's school fees and improve their livelihood. In future, he would like to buy land and expand his farm.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Vibol Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 16 people from Kong Noy village, Kandal province. The group members will use their portions of the loan for varied purposes.
Mrs. Sok V. is the village bank president who has been selected by the group members. She was born in 1960 and is the mother of one child who is 19 years old. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She also works as a tailor from her home while her husband, Mr. Hey Or, is a construction worker. It is now the season to grow rice, but Mrs. Sok V. does not have enough money to do this. Therefore, to improve production, Mrs. Sok V. is applying for a loan to farm rice this year.

loans.use: To farm rice this year

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn P. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. She is 38 years old. Jocelyn is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, snacks, sugar, detergents and biscuits. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital for the business. This will be the second loan taken by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital for the business

loans.name: Eden San

texts.en:
This is Eden San B., 49, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has five children, two of whom are already working while three are staying at home managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Eden has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Eden operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to buy one sachet of shampoo, five PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at the  wholesale price and selling at retail. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Eden dreams of being able to renovate her house soon through profits from all of her work. She faithfully meets with her fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn G. is from the village of Libertad, Gingoog City. She is 20 years old. Jovelyn is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Jovelyn owns and operates a business providing motorcycle or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jovelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jovelyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
This is Lucila M., 64, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo M., a driver, and is the mother of four children, all of whom are already finished with school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Lucila operates a tailoring business. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets, and other home trappings but also has seasonal demands for clothing like uniforms. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Lucila dreams that her business will be successful one day. She faithfully meets with her fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando P. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. He is 41 years old. Fernando is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Fernando owns and operates a retail store, buying and selling coconuts and bananas in the local community. Fernando has been engaged in his business for more than a year and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fernando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Fernando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fernando is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which he will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
This is Delia V., 65, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ulpiano V. and mother to four young hard-working adults. By the grace of God, Delia has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Delia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages, etc. to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Delia dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza T. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Eliza is married and has three children. To make a living, Eliza owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, biscuits, & junk foods in the local community. Eliza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Eliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Eliza is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Eliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida D. C. is a 61-year-old married woman with four children, who says that their life is the picture of a poor family. Because of lack of income their children got a low level of education. Her eldest son Rommel, 40 years old, finished high school and is now a construction worker (laborer), Marina, age 39, attained only high school education and is a housekeeper.  The second to the youngest is Ronald, 37 years old, who did  not finish high school and is now a helper. The youngest Ruby Jane, 19 years old, is still schooling. Three of her children have their own family right now.

Zenaida’s source of income comes from selling cashew nuts. That gives them only a small income due to the small amount of capital in her business. The income is not enough for their daily expenses. When Zenaida joined Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she used her loan to increase her working capital for more inventory of cashew nuts. Now, the business is now giving her income that helps her whole family. But she wants this business to grow more, so she decided to request a third loan from ASHI to buy more supplies of cashew nuts for better output.

Zenaida is really caring for her four children and her family; she wants to help them in her simple way. That’s why she is concentrating on her business so it can give her more income for them.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of cashew nuts

loans.name: Malikahon's Group

texts.en:
Halimahan J., 58, is the treasurer of the group. She is married and has three children.  Halimahon makes money by taking orders and sewing men's and women's clothes. In this way she earns 2000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money in order to repair the house. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. In the future she wants to expand her business and open a sewing workshop. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
This is Fe P., 65, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is already a widow and she is both father and mother to three young hard-working adults. By the grace of God, Fe has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Fe P. operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages, etc. to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Fe  dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages, etc.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina N. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old. Dina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Dina owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing karaoke or videoke services wherein the customers need to pay 5 pesos per song. Dina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Dina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the karaoke. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the karaoke machine

loans.name: Manuchehr

texts.ru: Ёрматов Манучехр проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 24 года. Холост. Образование среднее. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Он привозит миндаль и фисташки с района и продает на рынке города оптом.  Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Манучехр хочет получить больше прибыли, так как он намерен устроить свою свадьбу и расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en: Manuchehr Y. lives in the region of Shahrituz. He is 24 years old, not married. He has secondary education. He has been in sales for more than five years. He produces almonds and pistachios and sells wholesale on the market. He is taking out the loan to increase sales. Manuchehr wants to get more profit as he plans to celebrate his wedding and expand his business.

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mr. Sok S., 45, is a resident of Kompong Tom Province. He is a local farmer. Besides working as a farmer, he also works as a horse driver for tourists who want to visit the countryside, and picks up some products from his neighbors to transport to and from other provinces for additional income. 

Mr. Sok S. is married to Mrs. Bork Ya, age 45, also a local farmer. They are blessed with six children, and all of them are single. However, the family recently is facing difficulty with their living conditions due to their house needing repair. To solve the problem, Mr. Sok S. would like a loan to buy some pieces of wood to repair a part of his broken house. (His wife is pictured, because Mr. Sok S. was unavailable.)

loans.use: To buy some pieces of wood to repair a broken part of his house

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma B. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Elma is married and has four children. To make a living, Elma owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing pedicure & manicure services to local community members. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Elma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for the services. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Elma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Muhabbathon's Group

texts.en:
Muhabbathon M., 21, is the leader of this group.   She lives with her parents. They have their family business which is concerned with cattle breeding.  The family started to breed cattle five years ago with the initial investment of 15,000 soms.  Muhabbathon applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase cattle in order to resell them at a higher price after fattening.

Fatima B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 53 and married. Her husband is a welder. Together they are raising four children. Fatima is a teacher at school, but she is also engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle for breeding.

Hurshidahon B., 27, is married. Her husband is a welder. They have two children: a daughter and a son. With money received from the loan Hurshidahon wants to purchase a fridge in order to improve her living conditions. 

Abdulkahim A., 79, is married. He has raised two sons. The first son works in Russia and the second is engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan Abdulkahim wants to purchase a calf for breeding.

loans.name: Warren

texts.en:
Warren P. is from the village of Poblacion, Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 22 years old. Warren is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Warren runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, detergent, junk food, and candy, in the local community.
