Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.ar:
محمود عمره 41 سنة متزوج ولديه اربعة اولاد يعمل في مجال الادوات الصحية يعمل لحسابه الخاص يسعى لتطوير نفسه وعائلته من خلال تأمين  مدخول يساعد على العيش الكريم 
 يحب عائلته  وعمله له في مصلحته اكثر من 20 عام يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة ان يزيد مدخول مصلحته وشراء بضاعة جديدة للمصلحة بسب نقص المعدات اللازمة للعمل زبائنه 
من اصدقاءه ومحيطه  يريد التطور وتأمين عمل خاص به يتميز بألتزامه
texts.en: Mahmoud is a 41-year-old husband and father of four who is self-employed in the field of bathroom supplies and who hopes to further advance himself and his family by securing an income that will enable them to live in dignity. The applicant loves both his family and his work, which he has been involved in for more than twenty years. Through the loan to be provided by Al Majmoua, Mahmoud hopes to acquire new merchandise and equipment to better serve his customers (comprising his friends and other colleagues) with distinction.

loans.use: Purchase of new merchandise and equipment.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa A. is 36 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She is from Barangay 26, a part of Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental province on the islands of Mindanao. Elsa makes and sells snacks and other delicacies like steamed bananas and rice cakes to the local community. She has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase ingredients needed to make her snacks. Elsa is requesting a new loan, her fifth from HSPFI, of 14,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional ingredients and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and for working capital

loans.name: Buthayna

texts.en:
Buthayna is the young mother of one daughter and three sons. She is married to Ibrahim who runs a bakery in the city. The family lives in Gaza City in Gaza Strip. The bakery, which is their only source of income, produces different kinds of bread, including locA. breads such as Lebanese, Iraqi, etc. Buthayna and her husband started the bakery four years ago. The bakery supplies a large area around the center of the city as it's the only one producing a large variety of bread. Buthayna came to Kiva's partner, FATEN, for a loan to purchase larger amounts of wheat flour and baking materials as they are planning to double their production and increase their returns.

Buthayna's husband appears in the the bakery photo as Buthayna is very religious - as are most Gaza Strip citizens - and doesn't want her picture posted online.

About Shariah-compliant lending:
 
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the culturA. context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principA. loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour and baking materials

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en: Dolgor T. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her son, age 7, attends a local primary school. Her husband, Munhbat, supports the family by working at a variety of jobs. Dolgor operates a consumer goods sales business in a rented stall at a local market in the city. Currently her business is good, and she expanded her business by renting a stall in a different trade center. She started this business in 2007 and has built a stable and successful operation. Dolgor works hard to grow her business. With this loan, she hopes to expand her product line in the near future. She is requesting a 990,000 MNT loan to buy more products to sell.

loans.use: To buy more products.

loans.name: Enhjargal

texts.en:
Enhjargal U. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Uvs province, Mongolia. They have been living in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and fence for the past 14 years. Three of her sons attend a local secondary school. 

Enhjargal and her husband operate three kinds of businesses to make their living. She has been operating a meat trading business in her town, with the help of her husband, since 1995 and they have built a stable operation. She offers a variety of locally produced meats, those purchased from herders, to her customers by selling at the local market. In addition, they operate a vegetable and fruit planting business to supplement their family's income. They planted a variety of vegetables in a 0.5 hectare field and fruits, such as gooseberries and sea buckthorns, in their yard. They sell these products in the local community. 

With profits from their fruit and vegetable trading business, she has been able to buy a new van (at 4,000,000 MNT) for her husband, who operates a transportation business. After years of successful businesses, her family's standard of living has been improving greatly year by year. They are both very hardworking people. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more livestock to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock.

loans.name: Mendsaihan

texts.en:
Mendsaihan C. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and six children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of his children attend a local secondary school. 

Mendsaihan operates a firewood and coal sales business in his town. He started his business in 2007 by packing firewood and coal into bags and selling in the local community. He has built a stable operation. In addition, he also operates a vegetable planting and selling business to supplement his earnings. Moreover, he works in the construction field during the summer months, with help of his wife, to support his family. His business earnings have enabled him to provide for his entire family. He also has used his business profits to send his child for hospital treatment. 

Mendsaihan is a modest and honest man and says,  "I will work very hard everyday until my children will be grown up and become good people. " He is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase more coal for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more coal.

loans.name: Laarni

texts.en:
Laarni A. is from the village of Lunao, Gingoog City. She is 28 years old. Laarni is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Laarni owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Laarni has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Laarni joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Laarni is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Laarni from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Ulziibayar

texts.en:
Ulziibayar S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. The family lives in an apartment. Her daughter is an elementary school student while her son is only 6 months old. Her husband has helped with her business. 

Ulziibayar started her business in 2007, operating a grocery store till 2006, after working in Korea between 2003 and 2006. Currently she manages a successful cafe and bar in a rented space. She rents the cafe and runs it daily by hiring two employees. She pays monthly rental fees of 1,500,000 MNT and monthly salaries of 200,000 MNT per employee. Over the years of running the business, she has built a stable operation. Her average monthly income is around 6,000,000 MNT. In addition, she owns two apartments that are used as rental apartments. She earns 700,000 MNT per month by renting her these two apartments to others. She has used her earnings to support her family. She is planning to buy a new jeep car for her family from her business earnings in the future. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to pay customs duty tax for importing a new truck from Korea.

loans.use: To buy a new truck.

loans.name: Founé

texts.fr:
Né vers 1967  à  San, région de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) Founé N. n’as pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, alors elle  embrassa  très vite les activités génératrices de revenus. Mariée, mère de 8 enfants, elle vit chez son époux dans le quartier Santoro I de la ville de San. 
Elle fait l’achat vente de poissons sous diverses formes, depuis maintenant 7 ans et l’a appris auprès de son époux. Actuellement elle mène son activité au grand marché  de San où elle est très sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité de ses articles.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, elle décida de faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans.  Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel, après l’association. 
Madame Founé N. compte acheter, 600 kg de poisson frais et 450 kg de poisson  fumé. Elle  s’approvisionnait  auprès de revendeurs de San, mais avec l’augmentation du fonds de commerce, elle  compte aller jusqu’au bord du fleuve pour acheter directement  avec les pêcheurs. Elle  vend tous les jours au  grand marché de San à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant. 
Elle  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 102.500 FCFA qu’elle  envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et utiliser  le reste venir en aide a son époux dans les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Born in about 1967 at San in the Ségou area (the fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali), Founé N. did not have the good fortune to be able to attend school, so she rapidly devoted herself to income generating activities. She is married with 8 children and she lives with her husband in the Santoro 1 neighbourhood in the town of San.
She has been buying and selling various fish preparations for the last 7 years having learnt the business from her husband. At present she works in the big market in San where she is in great demand from her customers due to the high quality of her produce.
In her efforts to find additional financial resources, she decided to turn to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution two years ago. This is her second individual loan from the association.
Mrs Founé N. intends to purchase 600 kilograms of fresh fish and 450 kilograms of smoked fish. Up until now she has bought her supplies from the retailers of San, but with the expansion of her business she intends to go to the banks of the river to buy directly from the fishermen. She sells her wares every day at the big market in San for cash to a clientele made up of women and men. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 102.500 FCFA which she intends to use to repay the loan, keeping the remainder to help her husband with family expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of fresh and smoked fish.

loans.name: Hishigjargal

texts.en:
Hishigjargal D. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her older daughter, age 9, attends a local secondary school, while her younger daughter, age 2, attends kindergarten. 

Hishigjargal rents and operates a local public bath house, one of only two in the town. Bathhouses are important for local people as many of them do not have running water with which to bathe. She began her business in 2008 and has built a stable operation. Her husband supports her business by working as a fireman in the bath house. At first her monthly earnings were 300,000 MNT, but they have since increased to 500,000 MNT. After years of successful business, her profits have enabled her to start building a new house for her family. Hishigjargal is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase coals for her bath house.

loans.use: To purchase coals for her bath house

loans.name: Bricsio

texts.en:
Bricsio R. is from the village of Barangay 22, in Gingoog City. He is 59 years old, married, and has 3 grown children. To make a living, Bricsio owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts and bananas in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Bricsio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional bananas and coconuts to buy and sell. This will be Bricsio’s 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas and coconuts to buy and sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Nyambayar

texts.en:
Nyambayar M. is 25 years old and lives with her husband and son in the Tosontsengel province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rented apartment. Her husband is an accountant and works in a private company. Nyambayar operates a retail clothing business in the Republic of Tuvans. Her siblings currently live and work in Kyzyl, the capital city of the Republic of Tuva.  They rent and sell a variety of consumer goods in the local community.

Nyambayar is responsible for importing products from China while her sibling is responsible for selling the products in the market of Kyzyl. She began her business in 2008, first selling consumer goods, and has since expanded her product line by selling a variety of construction materials along with her goods-trading business.

For the future, she plans to have her own factory space. Nyambayar says, "Nowadays, a traveling business is not enough to support an entire family. I am planning to establish a manufacturing business by producing a variety of items so that my business might be profitable. Unfortunately, I cannot obtain a loan for a high amount, so therefore my earnings are not sufficient enough for my business."

She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to import children's clothing items as well as construction materials from China which her sibling can sell in the foreign market.

loans.use: To import children's clothing items

loans.name: Parissi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Parissi est composé sept  femmes  toutes mariées de la ville de Tènè, préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième région administrative de la république du MALI). Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et sont mères d’au moins 6 enfants.  Elles font de la restauration, la vente de condiments alimentaires, de pagnes wax, de tissus, de bijoux etc. 
Pour satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles qui ne cesse d’augmenter les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans. 
Hawa T. compte utiliser son prêt pour aller s’approvisionner à Bamako, en achetant, 15 pièces de wax, une douzaine de tissus pour enfants et deux douzaines de bijoux.   
Elle espère réaliser un  bénéfice de 22.500FCFA par mois. En plus du remboursement du prêt, elle utilisera une partie de son  revenu  pour l’entretien des enfants et les autres dépenses de la famille. En ce qui concerne les autres femmes du groupe, elles comptent sur un bénéfice de 18 000 francs FCFA par mois.
texts.en:
The Parissi group consists of seven married women who live in Tènè, in the San prefecture, within the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

They average 38 years of age and have at least six children each. Their activities revolve around the restaurant business and the sale of condiments, wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), fabrics, jewelry, etc.

In order to satisfy a steadily increasing customer base, the members of the group turned to the  Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution two years ago.

Hawa T. plans to use her loan to get supplies in Bamako. She will buy fifteen pieces of wax cloth, a dozen children’s fabrics, and two dozen jewelry pieces.

She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 22,500FCFA. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of her income for the children’s needs and other family expenses. As for the other group members, they expect a monthly profit of 18,000FCFA.

loans.use: Purchase of miscellaneous items

loans.name: Purevtseren

texts.en:
Purevtseren T. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  His oldest two children attend school while Purevtseren operates a gold and silver crafts business in his town.

He is a dexterous craftsman who received all his skills from his elders. He designs and produces a variety of jewelry and accessories using his father's equipment and tools. He has been engaged in this business for 8 years and has built a stable operation. For the future, he plans to have his own workplace next to his home.

Purevtseren is a modest man who is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase his mould and supplies from Erlian, a border city in China, for his jewelery making business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies from Erlian

loans.name: Marylou

texts.en: Marylou C. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marylou owns and operates a specialized retail store buying sacks of rice and selling it per kilogram in the local community. Marylou has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Marylou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marylou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marylou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Nuriym's Group

texts.en: Nuriym B. is the leader of the group. She is 40, divorced and has three daughters. The first daughter is a seller in a store, the second is at school and the youngest daughter is preschool age (under 7). Nuriyim works as a seller in a store, too, and she is also engaged in cattle breeding. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to build a new house. Mairamkul T., 52, is the treasurer of the group. She has a son who is 12 and studies at school. In order to earn money, Mairamkul sells apples and pears at the market. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase apples and pears for sale. Gulnura K., 26, is married. Her husband works as an inspector in the Tax Department. Together they are bringing up two daughters. Gulnura hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase clothes for her daughters. Aigul T., 22, is married and has a newborn son. Aigul and her husband are farmers. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase potatoes and coal for the winter season. b>====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Mohitob

texts.ru: Абдуллоева Мохитоб проживает в районе Фархор. Возраст, 27 лет. Замужем, детей не имеет. Образование высшее. Окончила институт предпринимательства и сервиса. Год как занимается торговлей. Имеет продуктовый магазин. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Mohitob A. lives in the Farkhor district.  She is 27 years old, married and does not have children.  She has a higher education.  She graduated from an entrepreneurial and service university.  Mohitob has been involved in retails sales for one year.  She owns a food store.  She is requesting this loan in order to increase the product assortment.

loans.use: Increasing product assortment

loans.name: Manibadar

texts.en:
Manibadar T. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, which is the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in an apartment.

He operates a transportation business for locals between towns.  He owns a large transport truck and transport goods throughout towns and cities. He started his transporting business in 2007 and has found success as a truck driver. In the winter he also purchases and transports coal which he sells to local residents and businesses.

After years of successful operation, he has gained many permanent customers. For the future, he plans to continue to grow and improve his business so that he can enlarge his house and fence. He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase four new tires and an engine for his  truck.

loans.use: To purchase new four tires and engine

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est constitué de quatre femmes de Kimparana dans la préfecture de SAN. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 8 enfants. Les membres du groupe  Benkadi  font la vente  de condiments, tissus, bijoux et diverses marchandises. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  cinq ans. Le groupe est à son huitième  prêt et  Sitan K.   compte acheter avec son prêt, 10 cartons de Cube maggi, 15 sacs  de gombo séchés, 5 sacs de 50 kg de sel de cuisine et 3 paniers de poivre. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée essentiellement  de femmes.
Elle espère réaliser un  bénéfice de 41.250 FCFA par mois. En plus du remboursement du prêt, elle utilisera  une partie de son  revenu  pour payer  les trousseaux des filles et autres dépenses de la famille. 
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ambitionnent agrandir leurs fonds de commerce et diversifier leurs marchandises.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is composed of four women lving in Kimparana, in the San prefecture. They are all married, and average 45 years of age and at least 8 children. The members of the Benkadi group sell condiments, fabrics, jewelry and miscellaneous goods. In order to increase the scope of their business, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program five years ago. The group is now on its eighth loan. 

Sitan K. plans to use her loan to purchase 10 boxes of Maggi bouillon cubes, 15 bags of dried gumbo, five 50-kg bags of table salt and three baskets of pepper. She buys her stock from wholesalers and sells retail for cash to a customer base composed mainly of women. She hopes to achieve monthly revenue of 41,250 West African Francs. Besides repaying her loan, she will use part of her revenue to pay her daughters’ wedding trousseau and other family expenses.

The members of the Benkadi family have a goal of increasing their working capital and diversifying their merchandise.

loans.use: Purchasing food condiments

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie G. is from the village of Barangay 23, Gingoog City. She is 30 years old. Melanie is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling used bags (or ukay-ukay bags) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $94 a month for these activities.

In 2003, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Melanie is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new consignment of drugs

loans.name: Oyunsuren

texts.en: Oyunsuren Z. is 30 years old. She lives with her husband and two daughters in an apartment in Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. Both of her two daughters attend a local school while her husband operates a taxi service using his car and helps with Oyunsuren's business. Since 2004, she has been purchasing second hand raw materials such as glass and plastic bottles, aluminum, copper and brass, etc. to sell for profits. After many years of operation, she has established a stable business and a good position in the business community. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a new car for her husband and to improve her family's standard of living as well. Over the years, she has gained not only in experience but also permanent suppliers. For the future, she plans to trade her car in for a big truck. Oyunsuren is a modest and honest woman and she is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan  in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital.

loans.name: Fotemogoban Group

texts.fr:
Fotemogoban est un regroupement de cinq  femmes toutes mariées de la ville  Tènè, préfecture de SAN, quatrième région administrative de la république du MALI.  Elles ont en moyenne 41 ans et au moins 4 enfants. 
Les femmes du groupe font l’achat vente de tissus, de bijoux, de condiments  alimentaires et de la restauration qui est la spécialité de Toula D.. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis cinq ans et est à son huitième  prêt solidaire. 
Toula D. compte acheter, 5 sacs de riz, 1 sac d’oignon frais, 1 sac de sel, 10kg de l’ail et 30000FCFA pour les petits condiments. Madame Toula D. vend tous plats alimentaires au carrefour de TENE. 
Elle compte sur un  bénéfice de 48000FCFA par mois qu’elle compte utiliser l’entretien de ses enfants, les trousseaux des filles et autres dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Fotemogoban is a group of five married women who come from the town of Tènè, in the prefecture of San, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They average 41 years of age and have at least four children each. 

The women in this group buy and sell fabric, jewelry and condiments, and are active in the restauration business (the latter is the speciality of Toula D.). In order to increase the volume of their businesses, the members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program five years ago and they are now on their eighth group loan.

Toula D. is planning to buy five sacks of rice, one sack of fresh onions, one sack of salt, 10kg of garlic and condiments to the value of 30,000FCFA. Mrs. D. sells all her dishes at the crossroads in Tènè. She is expecting to make a profit of 48,000FCFA per month, which she is planning to use to look after her children, for her daughters' trousseaux and for other family expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of restauration ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, meat, fish, cooking oil, onions, pepper, salt etc.

loans.name: Tsogtbazar

texts.en:
Tsogtbazar G. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two teenaged children in Tosontsengel province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of his children attend a local high school, while Tsogbazar operates a small tire repair shop outdoors. He began this service in 2008 after purchasing necessary equipment and tools for his repair center from his brother. He had stopped operating his tire repair business due to cold weather in winter months. He provides a high quality service for his customers, therefore has gained a positive reputation among his customers. 

He is planning to build a small wooden house where will operate his repair shop. For the future, he hopes to have his own car repair center. Since operating his business, his family's standard of living has been improving and with his earnings, he paid for his mother in law's funeral. Tsogtbazar says, "Even though I have a good educational background, I do not regret having to do physical labor. I am glad that my business earnings have helped my siblings and mother and other many people. I used my business profits to provide for my family and siblings who all are very grateful for my business." He is requesting an 500,000 MNT loan to purchase wood and timber in order to build a tire repair shop.

loans.use: To purchase wood and timbers.

loans.name: Balemayadjourou Group

texts.fr:
Balemayadjourou est un regroupement de quatre femmes de l’ex arrondissement de Kimparana, préfecture de San, qui ont en moyenne 43 ans,  sont mariées et mères d’au moins 6 enfants.  
Elles  font la vente de poisson frais, de la restauration et l’achat vente de  diverses marchandises. 
Le groupe a intégré le programme de  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis cinq ans. Il est à son huitième  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les sept précédents. 
Djeneba D. est la restauratrice du groupe qui est installée  au bord du goudron passant devant la gendarmerie. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10 sacs de farine de blé, 5 bidons d’huile de 20 litres et 25000 FCFA de condiments alimentaires pour la préparation de son beignet. 
Elle espère sur un  bénéfice de 49.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Balemayadjourou is a group of four women from the borough surrounding Kimparana in the San prefecture. On average they are 43 years old, married, and have at least six children.

They sell fresh fish and prepared foods and buy and sell diverse products. The group joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program five years ago. They are on their eighth group loan, having fully repaid the other seven.

Djeneba D. is the restaurant operator of the group whose business is located on the edge of the paved road running in front of the police station. She plans to use her loan to buy ten bags of wheat flour, five 20-liter cans of oil, and 25,000 FCFA's worth of condiments for the preparation of her fritters.

She hopes to make a monthly profit of 49,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and meet family needs.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for restaurant

loans.name: Apple Grace

texts.en:
Apple Grace J. is from the village of Barangay Napi, Gingoog City. She is 26 years old. Apple Grace is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Apple Grace owns & operates a specialized retail store, buying, selling & dealing in clothing, shoes, lotions, perfumes & deodorants products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community. Apple Grace has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Apple Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Apple Grace is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Apple Grace from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkan est constitué de quatre  femmes du village de Sienso Préfecture de San  Région de Ségou. Elles ont en moyenne 39  ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 9 enfants. Les membres du groupe Benkan font la vente  de condiments et diverses marchandises. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis quatre ans. Le groupe est à son sixième cycle de prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les cinq précédents. 
Minata D., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter, 3 cartons de cube maggi, 5 sacs de sel, du piment, du poivre, du Sounbala etc. 
Elle envisage réaliser un  bénéfice de 15.000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé en plus du remboursement du prêt, à assurer l’entretien de ses enfants, payer les trousseaux des filles et autres dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkan group is made up of four women from the village of Sienso, in the prefecture of San in the region of Ségou. They average 39 years of age, are married and have at least nine children. The members of the Benkan group sell condiments and various other goods.

In order to increase their business volume, the members joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program four years ago. The group is on its sixth solidarity loan, having repaid the five previous loans in full.

Minata D., the president of the group, is planning to buy four cartons of "Maggi" stock cubes, five bags of salt, chilis, pepper, sounbala (a pounded and fermented West African spice) etc. She is expecting to make a monthly profit of 15,000FCFA, which will be used not only to repay her loan but also to take care of her children, pay for her daughters' trousseaux and to cover other family expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouma est un constitué de quatre  femmes du village de   Sienso, Préfecture de San  Région de Ségou. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans,  sont toutes mariées et sont mères d’au moins 4 enfants. Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma font la vente de condiments et diverses marchandises. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le groupe est à son deuxième  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt. 
Behan T. qui est la présidente du groupe compte acheter, 5 cartons de cube maggi, 4 sacs de sel de cuisine, 5 paniers de piment, 3 paniers de Sounbala.  
Elle espère réaliser un  bénéfice de 20.000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et venir en aide aux conjoints dans les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouma group is made up of four women from the village of Sienso, in the San prefecture of the region of Ségou.  The women are, on average, 48 years old; they are all married and are the mothers of at least four children.  The members of the Sabougnouma group sell condiments and assorted merchandise.  In order to grow their businesses, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program two years ago.  The group is now on its second loan, having reimbursed the first loan on time.  

Bahan T., the group's President, plans to purchase five cases of Maggi cubes, four bags of table salt, five baskets of peppers, and three baskets of Sounbala.  She hopes to make a profit of 20,000 francs per month, which will be used to reimburse the loan and to help her partners with family expenses.

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old. Lolita is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Nyamayenje Tutungukye Group-Rukungiri

texts.en: B. Topther belongs to Nyamayenje Tutungukye group- Rukungiri. It is now 8 years since he began his grocery business in Nyamayenje.  Previously he was involved in a meat sales business. In a week his business generates shillings 150,000. He also has a banana plantation. Topther is married with four kids and he says with this loan he is going to purchase more foods such as avocados, potatoes, soft drinks and pineapples for resale.

loans.use: purchase of foods such as avocados, potatoes, soft drinks and pineapples for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of cement and sand

loans.name: Bwambara Women's Progressive Group-Rukungiri

texts.en: K. Jackson is 58 years old and belongs to Bwambara women's progressive group-Rukungiri. He is married with 11 kids and to take care of them he has for the last 10 years been running an agro-produce sales business in Rushaya. He has mostly been selling coffee, maize and rice. 500,000 shillings is the amount his business generates for him on a monthly basis. Prior to starting his business, he was a civil servant. He likes to describe himself as trustworthy. With this loan he says he is going to revamp his business with substantial purchases of bags of coffee and rice that he says he will at length resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of coffee and rice for resale

loans.name: Shallot

texts.en: A. Shallot is 38 years old and she has three kids. She has been operating her food sales business in Rukungiri food market for the last eight years. 100,000 shillings is what she makes in a week  principally out of selling bananas. She joined this business after much reflection on how this business would be of benefit to her in the long run. After all the second thoughts, she set forth. With this loan she says she wants to buy more manure for her banana plantations so that she can get better yields.

loans.use: The purchase of  more manure for her banana plantations
